Award.AbstractNarration:
Sea surface salinity (SSS) is a key indicator of the intensity of the water cycle over the oceans. It also has a strong influence on the stability of the upper ocean, which affects its propensity to mix vertically and thereby store or release heat and carbon dioxide. Thus, it has emerged as an important variable for understanding the Earth?s climate system. However, our data base on SSS is limited, salinity has always been a difficult measurement to make autonomously due to the challenges of biological fouling.

The PI's request funding to continue development of a self-cleaning conductivity sensor (and associated temperature and pressure measurements) with the goal of obtaining stable, long-term salinity measurements from a variety of ocean platforms. Deployment of such sensors on the drifters of the Global Drifter Program would provide a quantum leap in the numbers of SSS observations obtained and thereby make a substantial contribution to an improved understanding of the global water cycle requires a redesign to minimize the size and the manufacturing cost. In addition they propose to make a profiling model suitable for use on gliders and profilers. Their goal is to produce a sensor that will enable continuous monitoring of surface salinity from drifters in order to advance our understanding of the water cycle.

Broader Impacts:

This project develops a new capability to deploy low power salinity sensors with long-term stability in most of the platforms like drifters, moorings and AUV's. It's useful for the global drifter program. It is very useful for providing ground truth for the satellite derived salinity from SMOS (operational) and Aquarius (to be launched in June, 2011). Reliable long-term salinity measurements of the surface ocean are critical to accurately constrain the accelerating changes in the global water cycle, which are both predicted and appear to be occurring in response to global warming. The new sensor design should be commercially viable, thereby extending the scope of this proposal to include many more users such as with global ocean observing programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean salinity is a very important climate variable as it is a direct indicator of the intensity of the water cycle over the ocean.  That is, evaporation leads to higher salinity and precipitation leads to lower salinity. Since the oceans hold 97% of Earth’s water and all of the rainfall on land must ultimately come from the ocean, changes in ocean salinity are powerful indicators of how much water has been exported from any given region.  Recent work has shown that long term trends in ocean salinity, with salty areas getting saltier and fresh areas getting fresher, are indicative of the intensification of the water cycle associated with global warming. In addition, we have discovered that seasonal changes in near-surface salinity can be used to predict subsequent rainfall on land, because they are direct indicators of the export of water from ocean to land. Thus, it has become urgent to strengthen our observing capabilities for upper-ocean salinity.  This has always been a challenge, as biological fouling can quickly cause sizeable drift in the accuracy of salinity sensors. While the intensity of biological fouling varies with location, it is an increasing concern in all areas because we are using more and more autonomous platforms such as drifters, moorings, floats, and gliders to monitor the global variations in salinity, and it is the near-surface region where fouling pressure is most intense that is of the highest scientific interest and most value for seasonal rainfall prediction. The goal with autonomous platforms is to service them as little as possible and strive for the longest deployment intervals.  Thus, sensor longevity has become a high priority.  This development project designed and tested a new approach to antifouling protection for salinity sensors that uses ultra violet (UV) light and magnetically coupled mechanical scrubbing to prevent the colonization of the sensor volume with the initial bacterial films that precede fouling by larger organisms. It was found that only an intermittent application of UV light is required to maintain a clear sensor. We found that the UV light approach was simpler and sufficient to keep a sensor clean compared to the mechanical scrubbing; mechanical scrubbing was less reliable. The UV antifouling approach is being applied to a new project with salinity sensors on a surface “Wave glider” platform that will be subject to heavy fouling pressure. We are also exploring commercialization prospects for the new sensor design. The wide-spread usage of stable, long-lived salinity sensing technology will lead to improved understanding of the changing global water cycle.  And because of the close connection of upper-ocean salinity to moisture transport onto land, it will also contribute to better predictions of seasonal rainfall totals, droughts and extreme flooding events. Such capabilities will be very valuable to a society increasingly stressed by both drought and deluge.
